revision.text:
[[Image:Deesis.jpg|thumb|Icon of the Deesis [[St. Catherine's Monastery]] Sinai, 12th century)]] In [[Byzantine art]], and later [[Eastern Orthodox]] art generally, the '''Deësis''' or '''Deisis''' ({{lang-el|δέησις}}, "prayer" or "supplication"), is a traditional [[icon]]ic representation of [[Christ in Majesty]] or [[Christ Pantocrator]]: enthroned, carrying a book, and flanked by the [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Virgin Mary]] and [[St. John the Baptist]], and sometimes other saints and angels. Mary and John, and any other figures, are shown facing towards Christ with their hands raised in [[supplication]] on behalf of humanity.
In early examples, it was often placed on the [[templon]] beam in [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] churches or above doors, though it also appears on [[icons]] and devotional ivories.
After the development of the full [[iconostasis]] screen there was room for a larger "Deesis row" or "Great Deesis" of full-length figures, and the number of figures expanded, in both Byzantium and Russia. Usually this row is above the level of the doors, and below the row depicting the [[Twelve Great Feasts]], sometimes the Deesis is above the Feasts. The central Christ is therefore above the main door in the screen. Soon seven figures, usually one to a panel, were standard, in order of proximity to Christ in the centre: on the left (Christ's right) Mary, the [[Archangel Michael]] and [[Saint Peter]], and on the right John the Baptist, the [[Archangel Gabriel]] and [[Paul the Apostle|Saint Paul]]. Especially in Russian examples, a number of saints of local significance are often included behind these, as space allows. [[Andrey Rublev]]'s row for the Cathedral of the Dormition in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] were 3.14 metres (over ten feet) high. <ref>Maria Cheremeteff in Leong, Albert ed.;''The Millennium: Christianity and Russia, A.D. 988-1988''; p.110-8; 1990; St Vladimir's Seminary Press;{{ISBN|0-88141-080-2}}</ref> In the Greek tradition the Apostles are more likely to occupy extra panels.
The presence of Mary and John, and other figures, is one of the differences with the Western ''Christ in Majesty'', where the [[Four Evangelists]] and/or their symbols are more commonly included around Christ. The Deesis composition is also commonly found in the West, especially those parts of Italy under Byzantine influence, but also the rest of Europe. It often forms part of a scene of the [[Last Judgement]]. The use of the image declined slowly throughout the Middle Ages, and it is never as common as the Western forms of Christ in Majesty.
In depictions of the [[Crucifixion of Jesus]] Christ on the cross is also very often flanked by the Virgin standing on one side, but [[Saint John the Evangelist]] on the other, not John the Baptist.
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Triptych Harbaville Louvre OA3247 recto.jpg|[[Harbaville Triptych]], middle of the 10th century, ivory, Constantinople, [[Louvre]] Image:Iconostasis in Moscow.jpg|Five-panel Deesis row (center), [[Iconostasis]] in the [[Cathedral of the Annunciation, Moscow|Cathedral of the Annunciation]] in [[Moscow Kremlin]] by [[Theophanes the Greek]], 1405 - the first five-row Iconostasis Image:Cathedral Uglich inside 01.jpg|A larger Russian deesis row; [[Uglich]] Cathedral Image:Deesis_mosaic_Hagia_Sophia.jpg|Mosaic of the Deesis, 13th century, Hagia Sophia </gallery>
== References == {{Commonscat}} {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050804082309/http://www.artlex.com/ArtLex/D.html Definition of Deesis] -- Includes photos of the Deesis in the [[Hagia Sophia]].
[[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Iconography of Jesus]] [[Category:Virgin Mary in art]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox icons]]

{{notability|date=March 2010}}
The '''Fresh Fruit Festival''' is a publicly supported<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.charitiesnys.com/RegistrySearch/show_details.jsp?id={70BDAACC-A2DD-4E6D-8706-1578D5B2002B}|title=Charities Division NY State|last=|first=|date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-19}}</ref>, New York summer arts festival presented by All Out Arts, and featuring the work of [[LGBTQ]] artists as the primary expression of the All Out Arts mission of "Fighting prejudice and homophobia through the arts." It presents a multi-week main-stage presentation every July, and ancillary events year-round.
==History==
The Festival was founded by Carol Polcovar in 2002 as a merger of New Village Playwrights and New Village Productions reacted to a current reluctance on the part of major venues to present a truly representative array of LGBT arts. Originally sponsored by All Out Arts, Inc., a 501(c)(3) NY State non-profit since 1991, it shortly became a fully owned D.B.A. of All Out Arts. The Festival includes a wide range of plays, visual arts, dance, and film presentations. Along with the [[Hot! Festival]], it is among the most prominent LGBT-themed festivals in the New York artistic community. Carol Polcovar served as Founding Artistic Director of the festival for its first decade, and upon retirement in 2013 accepted an "Outstanding Achievement" Award for the Fresh Fruit Festival's mission from the Manhattan Borough President's Office.<ref>"I honor your commitment to the arts as a profoundly effective weapon against all forms of prejudice." -May 15, 2013- Gale A. Brewer, Borough President of Manhattan</ref>
==Ancillary programs==
The Festival presented the first of several "OUTmusic" programs in New York City, consisting entirely of vocalists, musicians, and composers who were Lesbian, Gay, Bi, or Transgendered. As Outmusic became an organization, All Out Arts served as their fiscal conduit and aided their becoming a unique organization. Outmusic is now a national foundation, sponsoring National Outmusic Awards since 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.outmusicawards.com/|title=Outmusic Awards The Biggest Night In LGBT Music & Entertainment|website=Outmusic Awards The Biggest Night In LGBT Music & Entertainment|access-date=2017-11-19}}</ref>
In 2006 the Festival presented the first event solely dedicated to and entirely by LGBT Native Americans. Native American elder Kent Lebsock presided over the opening convocation, and the event included members of the Cherokee, Mohawk, Chikasaw, Navajo, Creek , Lakota, Kumeyaay and Cree tribes. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tafoya|first1=Patrick|title=Roger Kuhn: A Two-Spirit Evening Proves Two Is Better Than One|journal=Talking Stick - Native Arts Quarterly|date=October 2006|issue=9.4 Oct/Nov/Dec 2006|url=http://amerinda.org/talkingstick/9-4/index.html}}</ref>
The Festival produces an annual winter OUT-wright Program, which facilitates developmental readings by LGBT authors, underwriting the expense of such events, as well as presenting lecture-demonstrations and public panels featuring published LGBT authors and poets.
==See also== * [[LGBT culture in New York City]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.freshfruitfestival.com The Fresh Fruit Festival Website] *[https://www.outmusicfoundation.org/ The Outmusic parent foundation] *[http://www.outmusicawards.com/ The Outmusic Awards page] [[Category:Theatre festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Summer festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in New York City]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]] [[Category:Arts festivals in the United States]] [[Category:LGBT arts organizations]]

[[File:Friedrich-winkler.jpg|thumb|right|Winkler ca. 1960]] '''Friedrich Horst Winkler''' (5 March 1888 - 23 February 1965)<ref name=kalliope>{{cite web|title=Winkler, Friedrich (1888-1965)|url=http://kalliope.staatsbibliothek-berlin.de/de/eac?eac.id=118769340|website=Kalliope|publisher=Staatsbibliothek Berlin|accessdate=17 February 2017|language=German}}</ref> was a German art historian specialised in German art, especially the works of [[Albrecht Dürer]], and [[Early Netherlandish painting]] from the 15th and 16th century.
==Biography== Friedrich Winkler was born at his family's farm in Prehna, a hamlet of [[Lumpzig]], Germany, in 1888.<ref name="DAH">{{cite web|url=http://www.arthistorians.info/winklerf|title=Winkler, Friedrich|last=|first=|date=|website=Dictionary of Art Historians|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> He studied art history at the [[University of Vienna]], the [[University of Berlin]], and the [[University of Freiburg]], where he studied under [[Wilhelm Vöge]]. His [[thesis]] ''Der [[Robert Campin|Meister von Flemalle]] und [[Rogier van der Weyden]]'', written in 1912, was published in 1913.<ref name=DAH/>
He then started working as the editor of the ''[[Thieme-Becker|Lexikon der bildenden Künstler]]'' by [[Ulrich Thieme]] and [[Felix Becker (art historian)|Felix Becker]], for which he wrote 34 entries. He also worked as a volunteer at the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]] in [[Dresden]], but then joined the army during [[World War I]]. He left the army in 1915 to become the director of the [[Kunstbibliothek Berlin]]. he wrote a work on Early Netherlandish [[Miniature (illuminated manuscript)|miniatures]], and in 1924 reworked ''Die Altniederländisch Malerei von 1400-1600'', originally written by [[Max Jacob Friedländer]]. In 1925 appeared ''Die Flämische Buchmalerei'', about Flemish miniature painting. In this period he married Hermina Christina Schützinger.<ref name=DAH/>
Winkler then started working on the ''[[Catalogue raisonné]]'' of the drawings by [[Albrecht Dürer]], which was started by [[Friedrich Lippmann]] (1838-1903). Winkler wrote the final two volumes of the catalog and a book about Dûrer, which were published in the late 1920s. In 1933 he succeeded the deceased [[Elfried Bock]] as Keeper of the [[Kupferstichkabinett Berlin]]. Between 1936 and 1939 he published a new catalogue of the drawings of Dürer in 4 volumes.<ref name=DAH/>
In 1942 he published a work on the drawings of [[Hans von Kulmbach]] and [[Hans Leonhard Schäufelein]], both pupils of Dürer. In 1947 he became a lecturer at the [[Humboldt University of Berlin]] and in 1951 he switched to Western Germany and the [[Free University of Berlin]], until he retired in 1957. That year he wrote ''Leben und Werke'', a biography of Dürer. After another work on Hans von Kulmbach, he published his final major work in 1964, ''Das Werk des [[Hugo van der Goes]]''.<ref name=DAH/> In 1950 he was made a corresponding member of the [[Bavarian Academy of Sciences and Humanities]].<ref name=Muller/>
A heart attack late in 1964 led to his death in February 1965.<ref name=DAH/>
==Bibliography== *1913: ''Der Meister von Flemalle und Rogier van der Weyden'' *1913-1914: ''Lexikon der bildenden Künstler'' (editor and writer) *1915: a study of Early Netherlandish miniatures *1924: ''Die Altniederländisch Malerei von 1400-1600'' (originally written by [[Max Jacob Friedländer]], in the [[Propyläen Kunstgeschichte]] series *1925: ''Die Flämische Buchmalerei des 15. und 16. Jahrhunderts'' *1927-1929: ''Zeichnungen von Albrecht Dürer in Nachbildungen'', volume 6 and 7 *1928: Monograph about Dürer *1936-1939: Drawings of Dürer, a catalogue in 4 volumes *1939: ''Altdeutschen Meisterzeichnungen aus der Sammlung Ehlers im Berliner Kupferstichkabinett''<ref name=Muller>{{cite web|last1=Müller|first1=Theodor|title=Nachruf Winkler Friedrich|url=https://www.badw.de/fileadmin/nachrufe/Winkler%20Friedrich.pdf|publisher=Bayerische Akademie der Wissenschaften|language=German}}</ref> *1942: Monograph about the drawings of Hans von Kulmbach and Hans Leonhard Schäufelein *1951: ''Dürer und die Illustrationen zum Narrenschiff''<ref name=Muller/> *1957: ''Leben und Werke'' *1950s-1960s: Monograph on Hans von Kulmbach *1964: ''Das Werk des Hugo van der Goes''
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}

'''Hyperrealism''' is a term coined by the [[composer]] [[Noah Creshevsky]] to describe a musical language for his and his colleagues' compositional aesthetic. Creshevsky defines this language as "''Hyperrealism is an electroacoustic musical language constructed from sounds that are found in our shared environment ("realism"), handled in ways that are somehow exaggerated or excessive ("hyper").''"<ref>http://www.kalvos.org/creshess2.html ''Hyperrealism, Hyperdrama, Superperformers and Open Palette'' - [[Noah Creshevsky]]</ref><ref>http://www.newmusicbox.org/article.nmbx?id=5117 ''A Language We Already Understand: Noah Creshevsky's Hyperrealism'' - [[Dennis Báthory-Kitsz]] - New Music Box</ref><ref>http://www.villagevoice.com/music/0427,gann,54855,22.html ''Slice 'N' Dice'' by [[Kyle Gann]], [[Village Voice]], July 6th, 2004 12:00 PM</ref>
==Articles and reviews==
* [http://www.secretdecoder.net/columns/2016/06/07/stuff-muzak-1-a-very-soft-focus-on-hyperrealist-music/ "STUFF MUZAK #1: A (VERY) SOFT FOCUS ON HYPERREALIST MUSIC"] by [http://www.secretdecoder.net/author/dwightpavlovic/ Dwight Pavlovic], Decoder Magazine, June 7, 2016 * [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/20/arts/music/20cdreview.html?_r=0 "Twilight of The Gods"] by [[Allan Kozinn]], [[The New York Times]], June 18, 2010 * [http://www.tokafi.com/newsitems/noah-creshevsky-know-and-not-know/ ''"Consistent lines: Creshevsky clearly builds his own reality."''], by Tobias Fischer, "Tokafi", November 30, 2007 * [http://www.newmusicbox.org/article.nmbx?id=5117 ''"A Language We Already Understand: Noah Creshevsky's Hyperrealism"''] by [[Dennis Báthory-Kitsz]], "[[NewMusicBox]]", June 13, 2007 * [http://www.kalvos.org/creshess2.html ''"Hyperrealism, Hyperdrama, Superperformers and Open Palette"''] by [[Noah Creshevsky]], "[[Kalvos & Damian New Music Bazaar]]", 2005 * [http://www.villagevoice.com/music/0427,gann,54855,22.html ''"Slice 'N' Dice"''] by [[Kyle Gann]], [[Village Voice]], July 6, 2004 * [http://www.transparencynow.com/eco.htm ''"Traveling Through Hyperreality With Umberto Eco"''], "Transparency"
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also==
* [[Hyperreality (art)]] * [[Hyperrealism]] * [[Hyperdrama]]
[[Category:Contemporary classical music]] [[Category:Realism (art movement)]]

The '''International Architecture Biennale Rotterdam''' (IABR) is a bi-annual international event bringing together international knowledge and experience in various design disciplines (architecture, urban planning and landscape architecture), and presenting this knowledge and experience to a broader audience.
Unlike other events such as the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture]], the IABR is a thematically designed research biennal; each edition addresses a pressing issue, from the perspective of current (Dutch) practices within an international context, and always with a focus on the future of the city.
The IABR implements its agenda by means of international research projects, exhibitions, master classes, workshops, conferences, lectures, debates, essays, a website, blogs, a catalogue, book, brochures, film, DVD, etc. Since the fourth edition, in 2009, the IABR has increasingly combined its research projects with concrete urban planning assignments. Particularly in the cities of Rotterdam, Istanbul and São Paulo, the biennale is actively involved in the actual development of the city.
The 7th edition of the IABR, THE NEXT ECONOMY–, opens in April 2016.
==Biennale Editions== * 2003 - Mobility: A Room with a View, curator [[Francine Houben]] (Mecanoo) * 2005 - The Flood, curator [[Adriaan Geuze]] (West8) * 2007 - Power: Producing the Contemporary City, curator [[Berlage instituut]] * 2009 - Open City: Designing Coexistence, curator [[Kees Christiaanse]] (KCAP, ETH Zürich) * 2012 - Making City, curator team Joachim Declerck, [[Henk Ovink]], ZUS (Kristian Koreman, Elma van Boxel), Asu Aksoy, MMBB/Fernando de Mello Franco and George Brugmans * 2014 - Urban by Nature, curator Dirk Sijmons (H+N+S, TU-Delft) * 2016 - The Next Economy, chief curator [[Maarten Hajer]] (University of Amsterdam, PBL Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency)
==External links== * [http://www.iabr.nl Internationale Architectuur Biennale Rotterdam] * [http://archinect.com/features/article/66092556/archinect-interviews-george-brugmans-iabr-part-1-making-city Interview with IABR–Director George Brugmans on Archinect] * [http://www.urbanista.org/issues/issue-1/features/making-city-5th-international-architecture-biennale-rotterdam-2012 Review of the 5th IABR: Making City on Urbanista.org] * [http://landscapearchitecturemagazine.org/tag/international-architecture-biennale-rotterdam/ Landscape Architecture Magazine on IABR–2014–URBAN BY NATURE–] * [http://www.uncubemagazine.com/blog/13619071 UNCUBE Magazine on IABR–2014–URBAN BY NATURE–] * [http://www.domusweb.it/en/architecture/2012/06/25/making-city.html Domus on the 5th IABR: Making City] * [http://www.domusweb.it/content/domusweb/en/architecture/2014/06/16/urban_by_nature.html Domus on IABR–2014–URBAN BY NATURE–]

{{Infobox ancient site | name = Izad-Khast Castle | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alternate_name = Izadkhast, Yazdkhast, Yazd khast | image = Izadkhast Castle by Hadi Karimi.jpg | image_size = | alt = Izadkhast Castle photo | caption = Izadkhast Castle as seen in August 2018. | map = | map_type = Iran | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | altitude_m = <!-- Enter a number for altitude in meters (m) --> | altitude_ref = | relief = | coordinates = {{coord|31|30|58|N|52|07|26|E|region:IR|display=inline,title}} | gbgridref = | map_dot_label = Izadkhast | location = [[Izadkhvast]], [[Abadeh County]], [[Iran]] | region = [[Fars Province]] | type = [[Castle]] | part_of = [[Complex of Izadkhast|The Complex of Izadkhast]] | length = | width = | area = | volume = | diameter = | circumference = | height = 6-15 metres (20-50 feet)<ref name="a1">{{cite web |title=Izadkhast Fortress |url=http://historicaliran.blogspot.com/2009/11/izadkhast-fortress.html |website=historicaliran.blogspot.com |accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref> | builder = | material = [[Adobe]] (World's first adobe castle)<ref name="a2">{{cite web |title=Izad Khast Castle – Abadeh |url=https://travital.com/attraction/izad-khast-castle-abadeh/ |website=travital.com |accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref> | built = [[Sasanian Empire|Sasanid]] (224-651 AD)<ref name="a2"></ref> | abandoned = | epochs = <!-- actually displays as "Periods" --> | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | discovered = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = Ruined | ownership = | management = | public_access = Yes | other_designation = on [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage]] Tentative List since 2007. | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | architectural_styles = [[Sassanid]], [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]] dynasty | architectural_details = | notes = }}
The '''Izad Khast Castle''' is located in [[Izadkhast]] in the [[Fars Province]], central [[Iran]]. The castle was built during the [[Sassanid Empire]] (224 to 651 AD)<ref name="a5">{{cite web |title=Izadkhast Fortress |url=http://historicaliran.blogspot.com/2009/11/izadkhast-fortress.html |website=HISTORICAL IRANIAN SITES AND PEOPLE |accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref> and functioned as fortified walled city on the ancient [[Silk Road]] that ran through central Iran. Izadkhast was the first castle in the world made from adobe.<ref name="a3"></ref> And it is the second largest adobe building in the world after [[Arg-e Bam]].<ref name="a3"></ref>
The castle is built on a high bedrock overlooking the Izadkhast valley. Inside the castle walls are many narrow alleyways and passages criss-crossing through centuries old tiny houses and buildings.<ref name="a3">{{cite web |title=Izad Khast Castle – Abadeh |url=https://travital.com/attraction/izad-khast-castle-abadeh/ |website=travital.com |accessdate=23 September 2018}}</ref>
The castle and surrounding [[Complex of Izadkhast|Izadkhast complex]] has been nominated to the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage]] Tentative List on August 9, 2007 in the Cultural category.<ref name="unescopage">[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5205/ The Complex of Izadkhast - UNESCO World Heritage Centre] Accessed 2018-09-23</ref>
== Location == [[File:Harold f Weston - Iran16.jpg|thumb|200px|left|1920s artwork of Izadkhvast Castle]]The Izad-khast castle is located on the ancient [[Silk Road]] between [[Shiraz]] and [[Isfahan]]. The site is in the middle of nowhere and surrounded by a desert land. But a high singular bedrock overlooking a valley was an ideal location for the development of a fortified desert city in the middle of nowhere.<ref name="a3"></ref>
The Izadkhvast castle is built on this singular bedrock that juts out to the Izadkhast valley. The valley around it functions as a natural deep trench. Castle fortification walls have been built around the bedrock, tall and almost perpendicular, ranging from 6 to 15 meters on three sides. On the fourth and shorter side of the bedrock, a 30 meter (100 feet) long trench had been dug. The trench is 4 meters across and 4 meters deep. Access to the castle was over the trench, through a small bridge and a gate.<ref name="a1"></ref>
[[File:The entrance of the big castle in Izad Khast - panoramio.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Entrance of the big castle over the trench.]]The site's natural topography and added fortifications made the castle one of the most unattainable buildings of the ancient times for robbers and enemies.<ref name="a3"></ref>
On the valley below the castle bedrock are rocky fields, with a barren plateau behind. The [[Izadkhast Caravanserai|Izadkhast caravanserai]] roadside inn stands alone in this valley, in the middle of a rocky field.<ref name="a4">{{cite web |title=Caravanserai as cultural crossroads along the Silk Roads: Iran’s Izadkhast |url=https://www.chasingtheunexpected.com/silk-road-iran-caravanserai/ |website=chasingtheunexpected.com |accessdate=24 September 2018}}</ref>
== History == The history of the castle complex dates back to the pre-Islamic era of Iran. Izad-Khast is a [[Sassanid]] castle, built during the [[Sassanid Empire]] (224 to 651 AD) which ruled [[Persia]] (Iran) and many parts of the surrounding countries.<ref name="a3"></ref> It was then used, added and improved on until [[Qajar dynasty|Qajars]] era (1794 to 1925). This has left works inside the castle belonging to different periods from [[Sassanids]] to [[Qajar_dynasty|Qajars]] with different architectural styles.<ref name="a1"></ref>
The fire temple of Izad Khast Castle from the Sassanid era was turned into a [[mosque]] after the advent of [[Islam]] to Iran.<ref name="a2"></ref>
The castle and complex is now completely abandon. However until the turn of the millennium there were still people living in the old quarters of Izadkhast. Floods in recent years destroyed many homes and forced people to move from this isolated, ancient desert citadel.<ref name="a1"></ref>
== Architecture == [[File:Izadkhast caravanserai - panoramio.jpg|thumb|200px|right|View of [[Izadkhast Caravanserai]] from castle.]]In location and form of construction the castle display unique characteristics. However the material wise its comparable to the [[Citadel of Bam]], [[Rayen Castle|Rayen]] and other sites nearby in Yazd and Kerman provinces. The architecture of Izadkhast castle is very similar to the more feted [[Citadel of Bam]]. The Izad-Khast castle like the Citadel of Bam is a sand construction, made of [[adobe]].<ref name="a2"></ref>
The castle is a [[Sassanid]] (224 to 651 AD) structure,<ref name="a1"></ref> but the interior has seen modifications and new structures added later on. Structures like a mosque and a bathroom are later additions.<ref name="a2"></ref>
Most of the homes in the castle interior are built from wood and mud. Size limitations of the bedrock led to an agglomeration of smaller rooms and increase of floors. Some of the buildings inside the castle rose as high as five storeys. It is impressive in itself but becomes a remarkable architectural achievement considering the circumstances of its time.<ref name="a1"></ref>
The [[Izadkhast Caravanserai]] was built during the [[Safavid Dynasty]] era (1502 - 1736).<ref name="a1"></ref>
==Threats== [[File:Izadkhvast ruins 02.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Crumbling ruins of the old castle town]]Many parts of the Izadkhast castle are crumbling due to erosion and flooding. Many homes even beside the castle front gate have been completely destroyed.<ref name="a1"></ref>
The castle is also in danger from treasure hunters and vandalism. Inside the walled city, there are signs of damage from treasure hunters and graffiti on the walls.<ref name="a1"></ref>
{{clear}} == Gallery == [[File:Izadkhvast Castle 07.jpg|thumb|550px|center|Izadkhvast Castle]]
<gallery mode="packed"> File:The entrance of Izadkhast old castle - panoramio.jpg|Entrance of the castle. Iran - Fars - Old Historical Castle in Izadkhast - panoramio.jpg|part of the old castle. Izadkhvast ruins 01.jpg|Ruins of the old town Izadkhvast Castle 04.jpg|The drawbridge of the castle Safavid-period bridge, Izadkhvast 01.jpg|[[Safavid]]-period bridge Izadkhvast Caravanserai 01.jpg| [[Samanid]] [[caravanserai]] near the castle of Izadkhast. </gallery>
==See Also== * [[Complex of Izadkhast]] * [[Izadkhast Caravanserai]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Iran]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{ mergeto | List of That '70s Show characters | discuss = Talk:List of That '70s Show characters#Proposal to merge 8 individual character articles into this article | date = August 2018 }} {{multiple issues| {{Notability|fiction|date=January 2009}} {{In-universe|subject = television|category = television|date = October 2009}} {{refimprove|date=September 2016}} }} {{Infobox character | name = Kitty Forman | series = [[That '70s Show]] | image = | first = "[[That '70s Pilot]]"
(episode 1.01) | last = "[[That '70s Finale]]"
(episode 8.22) | creator = [[Mark Brazill]] | portrayer = [[Debra Jo Rupp]]
[[Ashley Peldon]] (Teenage Kitty) | lbl21 = Birth name | data21 = Katherine Anne Sigurdson | gender = Female | occupation = [[Housewife]]
[[Nurse]] | family = Burt Sigurdson (father, deceased)
[[Bea Sigurdson]] (mother)
[[Paula Sigurdson]] (sister) | spouse = [[Red Forman]] | children = [[Laurie Forman]]
(daughter, with Red)
[[Eric Forman]]
(son, with Red)
[[Steven Hyde]] (foster son, with Red) | relatives = Albert Forman (father-in-law, deceased)
Bernice Forman (mother-in-law, deceased)
Marty Forman (brother-in-law)
Jerry Forman (brother-in-law)
[[Fez (That '70s Show)|Fez]] (former son-in-law)
Penny Sigurdson (niece) | nationality = [[United States|American]] }} '''Katherine Anne "Kitty" Forman''' (née '''Sigurdson''') is a [[fictional character]] on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Network's]] ''[[That '70s Show]]'', portrayed by comic actress [[Debra Jo Rupp]]. A nurse, she has taken breaks from her career when it was economically practical, to nurture her family. Nurturing but enabling, she has a very recognizable laugh whenever she is nervous about anything (which is often), a fondness for square dancing, and an even greater fondness for liquor of almost all kinds (wine, kahlua, bourbon, mai tais, margaritas, etc.) She puts her family first and tries to smooth over the many conflicts within her household, although her efforts often fail. She is also an unofficial foster mother to the entire group. ==About Kitty Forman== Kitty is Eric and Laurie Forman's mother and the wife of [[Red Forman]]: a cheerful, sunny, sweet-natured typical housewife with a much happier, gentler personality as opposed to that displayed by her ill-tempered, wisecracking husband, Red. She almost always treats those around her sweetly and kindly and shows far more respect for the teenagers than Red does. She cooks a great deal and often uses food to encourage and cheer people up. She has occasionally been provoked into using profanity strong enough to be censored out, albeit otherwise she seldom raises her voice to other people. She smoked frequently for a period of time before deciding to quit the habit, although when stressed she has been shown to relapse, even taking a cigarette from one of the teenagers when desperate, due to an unexpected visit from her mother-in-law, who treats her shabbily. ==Her parents== Kitty's parents generally generate stress for both Kitty and Red, particularly her rather cold, unaffectionate, hypercritical mother, Bea (played by [[Betty White]]). Kitty's genial but rather hapless father, Burt (played by [[Tom Poston]]), evokes more affection. Burt makes a terrible financial investment in an ostrich farm (located next to a coyote farm) which costs the Sigurdsons their home, leaving them dependent on the Formans. He collapses outside the house and dies soon afterward, the only occasion on which Bea shows emotion, albeit privately until Kitty finds her. ==Relationship with the kids== Unlike Red, Kitty enjoys having young people around her house. In regards to her children, she clearly favors Eric. She sees Laurie's true colors (unlike Red, who favors Laurie and browbeats Eric) and once said she loves her daughter "because I have to". She sometimes tries to get through to Laurie, almost always without success. Upon learning Eric has lost his virginity (episode "The Parents Find Out") she stays in bed, depressed and angry at Donna, only leaving bed when Eric reminds her that he needs Kitty to protect him from Red. For a time, she is sad that her children are growing up and expresses a desire for another baby, episode "[[List of That 70's Show episodes|Baby Fever]]", a feeling her husband does not share. Kitty resolves her sadness over not being able to have another child when Red reminded her of grandchildren. When Eric and Donna announce that they are moving to [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]] at the end of season five, Kitty suffers a nervous breakdown, exacerbated by Red's support of the plan. Later, when Eric plans to go to [[Africa]] in season seven, Kitty tries to sabotage his efforts by withholding food and information on [[immunization]]s. After he leaves at the start of season eight, Kitty briefly tries [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]. Kitty is fond of Hyde, whom they take in after his mother abandons him, leaving him nowhere to go. In the episode "[[Kitty's Birthday (Is That Today!?)]]", Hyde is the only one who remembers her birthday, and in the episode "[[List of That 70's Show episodes|Jackie Bags Hyde]]", Kitty is the one who helps Hyde realize he likes Jackie. Kitty treats Hyde as a second son even after he moves out of the Forman basement. In the series finale, she referred to him as "my second son". Kitty treats Eric's other friends [[Michael Kelso|Kelso]], [[Fez (That '70s Show)|Fez]] and [[Jackie Burkhart|Jackie]] as her own children as well; she looks out for them and helps them out on numerous occasions throughout the series. For example, she taught the prenatal class Kelso and Brooke take before Betsy's birth, she attempts to teach Jackie how to bake on two occasions, and she behaves as a mother to Fez, who hasn't seen his real parents since emigrating to the United States. Being a nurse and a maternal figure, she is the one who treats the teenagers whenever they get physically injured (which happens quite often), especially Kelso. Kitty plays an active role in all the group's private lives; for example, she is the one who orchestrated the talk between Jackie and her mother Pam (played by [[Brooke Shields]]) in season six. Kitty seems to dislike anyone who questions her values, telling Jackie to "shut your dirty little mouth" when she references Kitty's frequent drinking; and when Kelso asks if she'd ever smoked, she stared at him and Red makes him leave. Despite being a motherly figure to all of the teens, Kelso and Fez seem to have some sexual attraction towards her. Fez admits this to Charlie Richardson after he sees Kitty naked accidentally, asking what she looked like and saying, "And I'm only asking this because I find Miss Kitty attractive in a sexual way." Also, after Kelso has a break up with Hyde's sister, Angie, he tells Eric, "I need a hug from your mom." Eric concludes his conversation with Hyde, leaving to "go pull Kelso off my mother". Also, Hyde, before his (technically not legal) adoption made him Kitty's son, demonstrated some attraction to Kitty, such as when she was teaching him dancing, he greatly enjoyed placing his hand in the small of her back, almost sexually. As part of the plot of that episode, Bob sees them and assumes they are having an affair. In season eight, with Eric gone, she seemingly replaces him with Fez. Fez begins dating a friend of hers and when she finds out, she snaps and demands he break it off, to which he replies, "You can't tell me what to do. You're not my mother."{{cite episode|title=Good Company|episodelink=That '70s Show (season 8)#ep186|series=That '70s Show|serieslink=That '70s Show|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|date=January 12, 2006|season=8|number=8|time=12:22}} Kitty takes great offense to this and storms off and makes herself a blender full of alcohol. Donna and Jackie help Fez realize that Kitty has been the closest thing he has to a mother and she thinks of Fez as her own son. Fez makes up with Kitty afterward. ==References== {{reflist}} {{That '70s Show}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Forman, Kitty}} [[Category:Fictional American people of Swedish descent]] [[Category:Fictional characters from Wisconsin]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1998]] [[Category:Fictional nurses]] [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:That '70s Show characters]]

page.title: Le Monde's 100 Books of the Century

revision.text:
The '''100 Books of the Century''' ({{lang-fr|Les cent livres du siècle}}) is a list of the one hundred best books of the 20th century, according to a poll conducted in the spring of 1999 by the French retailer [[Fnac]] and the Paris newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]''. Starting from a preliminary list of 200 titles created by bookshops and journalists, 17,000 French voters responded to the question, "Which books have remained in your memory?" (''Quels livres sont restés dans votre mémoire ?'').{{cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=46796 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120527083227/http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=46796 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 May 2012 |title=Écrivains et choix sentimentaux |trans-title=Authors and sentimental choices |first=Josyane |last=Savigneau |author-link=Josyane Savigneau |newspaper=Le Monde |language=French |date=15 October 1999 |df= }} The list of acclaimed titles mixes great novels with poetry and theatre, as well as the [[Asterix the Gaul |Asterix]] comic book. The list includes many [[French novels]] because of the demographics of the surveyed group. However, similar lists by English language sources include US and UK authors only (for example, the [[Modern Library 100 Best Novels]] published in 1998, with two lists, one by the Board of the Modern Library and the other by readers who responded). ==List== {|class="wikitable sortable centre" !scope=col |No. !scope=col |Title !scope=col |Author !scope=col |Year !scope=col |Language |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 1 |''[[The Stranger (Camus novel)|The Stranger]]''

Jacobs]] |[[1950 in literature|1950]] |[[French language|French]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 91 |''[[The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge]]'' |[[Rainer Maria Rilke]] |[[1910 in literature|1910]] |[[German language|German]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 92 |''[[Second Thoughts (Michel Butor novel)|Second Thoughts]]'' |[[Michel Butor]] |[[1957 in literature|1957]] |[[French language|French]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 93 |''[[The Origins of Totalitarianism]]''
''The Burden of Our Time'' |[[Hannah Arendt]] |[[1951 in literature|1951]] |[[English language|English]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 94 |''[[The Master and Margarita]]'' |[[Mikhail Bulgakov]] |[[1967 in literature|1967]] |[[Russian language|Russian]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 95 |''[[The Rosy Crucifixion]]'' |[[Henry Miller]] |[[1949 in literature|1949]]–[[1960 in literature|60]] |[[English language|English]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 96 |''[[The Big Sleep]]'' |[[Raymond Chandler]] |[[1939 in literature|1939]] |[[English language|English]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 97 |''[[Amers]]'' |[[Saint-John Perse]] |[[1957 in literature|1957]] |[[French language|French]] |---------------------------------- |align="right" | 98 |''[[Gaston (comics)|Gaston]]''

|[[English language|English]] |} Note: Classified by the language of the book's first publication, which may not be the author's principal language. ==See also== *[[Bokklubben World Library]] (Norway) *[[List of Nobel laureates in Literature]] (Sweden) – including Camus, Steinbeck, Hemingway, Beckett, Sartre, Solzhenitsyn, Gide, García Márquez, Faulkner, Mauriac, Mann, Pirandello, Böll, Lagerlöf, Le Clézio, and Perse *[[Grand Prix du roman de l'Académie française#List of the laureates|List of recipients of the Grand Prize of the Académie française]] (France) – including de Saint-Exupéry, Cohen, Mauriac, Bernanos, and Tournier *[[Prix Goncourt#Prix Goncourt|List of recipients of the Prix Goncourt]] (France) – including Proust, Malraux, de Beauvoir, Tournier, Gracq, and Duras *[[Prix Renaudot#Prix Renaudot laureates|List of recipients of the Prix Renaudot]] (France) – including Céline, Perec, Aragon, Le Clézio, and Beigbeder *[[Prix mondial Cino Del Duca#Honorees|List of recipients of the Prix mondial Cino Del Duca]] (France) – including Kundera, Borges, Kadare, and Styron *[[Prix Médicis|List of recipients of the Prix Médicis]] (France) – including Eco, Perec, and Kundera *[[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction|List of recipients of the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] (US) – including Steinbeck, Hemingway, Faulkner, Mitchell, and Styron *[[Neustadt International Prize for Literature#List of Neustadt Laureates|List of recipients of the Neustadt Prize for Literature]] (US) – including García Márquez *[[Austrian State Prize for European Literature#Award winners|List of recipients of the European Literary Award]] (Austria) – including de Beauvoir, Eco, Ionesco, Kundera, Duras, and Rushdie *[[Jerusalem Prize#List of Laureates|List of recipients of the Jerusalem Prize]] (Israel) – including de Beauvoir, Ionesco, Kundera, Borges, and Kadare *[[Strega Prize#Winners|List of recipients of the Strega Prize]] (Italy) – including Eco, Buzzati, Moravia, and Levi *[[Prince of Asturias Awards#Literature|List of recipients of the Prince of Asturias Award]] (Spain) – including Kadare *[[Miguel de Cervantes Prize#Cervantes Prize winners|List of recipients of the Cervantes Prize]] (Spain) – including Borges *[[Western canon]] **[[Great Books of the Western World]] *[[Modern Library 100 Best Novels]] (US) – all were first published in English *[[TIME's List of the 100 Best Novels|''TIME'''s List of the 100 Best Novels]] (US) – all were first published in English *[[The Big Read]] (UK) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== Millennial/Centennial/Decennial/Annual Reassessment], overview of Best of Century lists {{Books}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Le Monde''{{'s}} 100 Books of the Century}} [[Category:Lists of books]] page.title: List of television series made into books

revision.text:
Often a [[television series]] becomes so successful and popular or attains such a cult status that the franchise produces books either directly based on it (adapted from the episode scripts) or strongly inspired by it (but describing new adventures of the characters).
==Television series== The following is a list of television series which were used as the basis for novels (see also [[:Category:Novels based on television series|Category:Novels based on television series]]).
<!--New additions must pass notability and the television series must have an article, the novels should be mentioned there; all other entries will be deleted--> *''[[All About Us (TV series)|All About Us]]'' see: [[All About Us (TV series)#Novels|''All About Us'' novels]] *''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]''; see: [[List of Angel novels|List of ''Angel'' novels]] * Auf Wiedersehen pet (1983 TV series) *''[[Beauty and the Beast (1987 TV series)|Beauty and the Beast]]''; see: [[Beauty and the Beast (1987 TV series)#Novelizations|''Beauty and the Beast'' novelizations]] *''[[Being Human (UK TV series)|Being Human]]''; see: [[Being Human novels|''Being Human'' novels]] *''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]''; see: [[Beverly Hills 90210#Novelization|''Beverly Hills'' books]] *''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]''; see: [[List of Buffy the Vampire Slayer novels|List of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' novels]] * ''[[Castle (TV series)|Castle]]''; see [[Castle (TV series)#Tie-in works|Castle tie-in works]] *''[[Catweazle]]''; see: [[Catweazle#Books|''Catweazle'' novels]] *''[[Charmed]]''; see: [[List of Charmed books|List of ''Charmed'' books]] *''[[Class (2016 TV series)|Class]]''; see: [[Class (2016 TV series)#Novels|''Class'' books]] *''[[Columbo]]''; *''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]''; see: [[CSI (novels)|''CSI'' novels]] *''[[CSI: Miami]]''; see: [[CSI (novels)|''CSI'' novels]] *''[[CSI: NY]]''; see: [[CSI (novels)|''CSI'' novels]] *''[[Dad's Army]]''; see: [[List of Dad's Army books and memorabilia|List of ''Dad's Army'' books and memorabilia]] *''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]]''; see: [[Dallas (1978 TV series)#Books and other media|''Dallas'' books]] *''[[Dark Shadows]]''; see: [[Dark Shadows#Novels|''Dark Shadows'' books]] *''[[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman]]''; see: [[Dr Quinn#Novels|''Dr. Quinn'' books]] *''[[Doctor Who]]''; see: [[List of Doctor Who novelisations|''List of Doctor Who'' novelisations]] *''[[Dynasty (1981 TV series)|Dynasty]]''; see: [[Dynasty (1981 TV series)#Commercial tie-ins|''Dynasty'' books]] *''[[Flight 29 Down]]''; see: [[Flight 29 Down#Book releases|''Flight 29 Down books]] *''[[Full House]]''; see: [[Full House#Book series|''Full House'' books]]'' *''[[Ghost Whisperer]]''; see: [[Ghost Whisperer#Novels|''Ghost Whisperer'' novels]] *''[[Ghostwriter]]''; see: [[Ghostwriter_(book_series)|''Ghostwriter'' books]] *''[[Grimm (TV series)|Grimm]]''; see: [[Grimm (TV series)#Books|''Grimm'' novels]] *''[[Hannah Montana]]''; see: [[List of Hannah Montana books|List of ''Hannah Montana'' books]] *''[[Highlander: The Series]]''; see: [[Highlander: The Series#Books|Highlander: The Series novels]] *''[[Life on Mars (UK TV series)|Life on Mars]]''; see: [[Life on Mars (UK TV series)#Novels|''Life on Mars'' novels]] *''[[Lizzie McGuire]]''; see: [[Lizzie McGuire books|''Lizzie McGuire'' books]] *''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]''; see: [[Millennium (TV series)#Books|''Millennium'' books]] *''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]''; see: [[Monk (TV series)#Novel series|''Monk'' books]] *''[[Murder, She Wrote]]''; see: [[List of Murder, She Wrote novels]] *''[[My So-Called Life]]''; see: [[My So-Called Life#Sequel novel|''My So-Called Life'' novel]] *''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]''; see: [[Once Upon a Time (TV series)#Novels|''Once Upon a Time'' novel]] *''[[The Originals (TV series)|The Originals]]''; see: [[The Originals (TV series)#Novels|''The Originals'' novels]] *''[[Primeval (TV series)|Primeval]]''; see: [[List of Primeval books and novelisations|List of ''Primeval'' books and novelisations]] *[[Psych (TV series)|Psych]]; see: [[Psych (TV series)#Novels|Psych novels]] *''[[Quantum Leap]]''; see: [[Quantum Leap#Other media|''Quantum Leap'' books]] *''[[Revenge (TV series)|Revenge]]''; see: [[Revenge (TV series)#Development and production|''Revenge'' book]] *''[[Red Dwarf]]''; see red dwarf trilogy [[Grant Naylor]] *''[[Roar (U.S. TV series)|Roar]]''; see: [[Roar (U.S. TV series)#Books|''Roar'' books]] *''[[Roswell (TV series)|Roswell]]''; see: [[Roswell (TV series)#Novels|''Roswell'' novels]] *''[[Sabrina the Teenage Witch (1996 TV series)|Sabrina, the Teenage Witch]]''; see: [[List of Sabrina, the Teenage Witch Books, CDs and DVDs|''Sabrina'' books]] *''[[The Sarah Jane Adventures]]''; see: [[Space: Above and Beyond#Novelization|''Space: Above and Beyond'' books]] *''[[Star Trek]]''; see: [[List of Star Trek novels|List of ''Star Trek'' novels]] *''[[Teen Wolf (2011 TV series)|Teen Wolf]]''; see: [[Teen Wolf (2011 TV series)#Book|''Teen Wolf'' novels]] *''[[Torchwood]]''; see: [[List of Torchwood novels and audio books|List of ''Torchwood'' novels and audio books]] *''[[The Tribe (1999 TV series)|The Tribe]]''; see: [[The Tribe (1999 TV series)#Book releases|''The Tribe'' novels]] *''[[Twin Peaks]]''; see: [[Twin Peaks books|''Twin Peaks'' books]] *''[[Two of a Kind (U.S. TV series)|Two of a Kind]]''; see: [[Two of a Kind (U.S. TV series)#Books|''Two of a Kind'' books]] *''[[The Vampire Diaries]]''; see: [[The Vampire Diaries (novel series)#Stefan.27s Diaries|''Stefan's Diaries'']] *''[[The X-Files]]''; see: [[The X-Files literature|''The X-Files'' literature]]
== Web series == The following is a list of web series which were used as the basis for novels. *''[[I Heart Vampires]]''; see: [[I Heart Vampires#Book|''I Heart Vampires: Birth (A Confessions of a High School Vampire Novel)'']]

page.title: List of video games derived from mods

revision.comment: /* List */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[Open-source software|open source]], [[open-source]] → [[Open-source software|open-source]]
revision.text:
This is a list of standalone [[video game]]s that have been ported from a [[Mod (video gaming)|modification]] of another video game, and/or that are entirely based on a modification of another video game. A game is considered standalone when it does not require the purchase or installation of any other game (including separate [[Game engine|engine software]] such as the [[Source SDK]]) in order to run. ==List== {{Inc-vg|date=March 2016}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ |- ! data-sort-type="text" | Game ! data-sort-type="text" | Original dependency ! class="unsortable" | Mod release ! class="unsortable" | Standalone release ! class="unsortable" | Additional information |- | ''[[Alien Swarm]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]'' | 28 May 2004 | 19 July 2010{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/630/ |title=Alien Swarm |accessdate=12 March 2016 |work=[[Steam (software)|Steam]] |publisher=[[Valve Corporation]]}} | The standalone version was developed by [[Valve Corporation]] and ported to the [[Source (game engine)|Source engine]]. |- | ''[[Angels Fall First: Planetstorm]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 20 October 2008{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/angels-fall-first-planetstorm/news/angels-fall-first-planetstorm-v100-released |title=Angels Fall First: Planetstorm V1.00 Released! |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | 1 October 2015{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/367270/ |title=Angels Fall First |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Antichamber]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 2009 | 31 January 2013{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219890/ |title=Antichamber |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The mod was originally known as ''Hazard: The Journey of Life''.{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/07/06/indie-game-hazard-the-journey-of-life-is-now-antichamber/ |title=Indie game 'Hazard: The Journey of Life' is now Antichamber |date=7 June 2011 |author=JC Fletcher |publisher=[[Engadget]] |accessdate=12 March 2016}} |- | ''[[The Ball (video game)|The Ball]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 2008 | 26 October 2010{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/the-ball/news/release35 |title=The Ball Released! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Black Mesa (video game)|Black Mesa]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 14 September 2012 | 5 May 2015{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890/ |title=Black Mesa |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The game is the remake of [[Valve Corporation]]'s game [[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]. |- | ''[[Chivalry: Medieval Warfare]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 10 September 2011 | 16 October 2012{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219640/ |title=Chivalry: Medieval Warfare |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The original mod was called ''[[Age of Chivalry]]''. The standalone version did not use the [[Source Engine]] like ''Half-Life 2''. Instead, it was developed for [[Unreal Engine 3]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesetwatch.com/2011/03/chivalry_firstperson_online_me.php |title=Chivalry: First-Person Online Medieval Combat |date=18 March 2011 |author=Eric Caoili |publisher=[[GameSetWatch]] |accessdate=12 March 2016}} |- | ''[[Counter-Strike (video game)|Counter-Strike]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 19 June 1999 | 8 November 2000 | The game received [[Counter-Strike|multiple sequels]] and a [[Source Engine]] remake named ''[[Counter-Strike: Source]]''. |- | ''[[Cry of Fear]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 22 February 2012{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/cry-of-fear/news/cry-of-fear-released |title=Cry of Fear - Released! |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | 25 April 2013{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/news/10472/ |title=Now Available - Cry of Fear |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[D-Day: Normandy]]'' | ''[[Quake II]]'' | 2000{{cite web |url=http://www.ddaydev.com/site/docs.php?go=aboutdday |title=Welcome to D-Day: Normandy! |accessdate=14 March 2016}} | 2002 | |- | ''[[The Dark Mod]]'' | ''[[Doom III]]'' | 17 October 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-dark-mod/news/its-here2 |title=Its Here! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 14 April 2013{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-dark-mod/news/the-dark-mod-20-standalone |title=The Dark Mod 2.0 Standalone! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | Several demo missions were released before the mod was made available, the first of which went up for download on 18 January 2008,{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-dark-mod/news/the-dark-mod-alpha-tech-demo-available |title=The Dark Mod: Alpha Tech Demo Available |accessdate=13 March 2016}} nearly two years before the mod was actually released. |- | ''[[Day of Defeat]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 2001 | 1 May 2003 | The game received a [[Source Engine]] remake named ''[[Day of Defeat: Source]]''. |- | ''[[Day of Infamy (video game)|Day of Infamy]]'' | ''[[Insurgency: Modern Infantry Combat|Insurgency]]'' | 16 January 2016 {{cite web |url=https://steamcommunity.com/workshop/filedetails/?id=604418860|title=Day of Infamy Steam workshop page |accessdate=3 September 2016}} | 23 March 2017 | A WWII remake of Insurgency: Modern Infantry Combat. Still in [[Early access]]. |- | ''[[DayZ (video game)|DayZ]]'' | ''[[ARMA 2]]'' | 21 February 2013 | 16 December 2013 | The standalone version is still in the [[Software release life cycle#Alpha|alpha]] stages of development. |- | ''[[PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds]]'' | ''[[ARMA 3]]'' | 9 Apr, 2015http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=421900169 | 20 Dec, 2017http://playbattlegrounds.com/news/24.pu | "PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds" is standalone version of "PlayerUnknown's Battle Royale" Mod from [[Arma 3]]. http://playbattlegrounds.com/news/24.pu |- | ''[[Dear Esther]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 2008 | 14 February 2012{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/203810|title=Dear Esther on Steam|work=[[Steam (software)|Steam]]|accessdate=2016-10-07}} | |- | ''[[Dota 2]]'' | style="white-space: nowrap;" | ''[[Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos]]'' | 2003 | 9 July 2013{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/570/ |title=Dota 2 |accessdate=12 March 2016}} | The rights to the original mod (''[[Defense of the Ancients]]'') were acquired by [[Valve Corporation]] and a derived standalone game was developed in the [[Source Engine]]. It has since been ported to [[Source 2]].{{cite web|last=Reilly |first=Jim |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2012/05/11/valve-blizzard-reach-dota-trademark-agreement.aspx |title=Valve, Blizzard Reach DOTA Trademark Agreement |date=May 11, 2012 |accessdate=March 30, 2016 |publisher=[[Game Informer]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724090129/http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2012/05/11/valve-blizzard-reach-dota-trademark-agreement.aspx |archivedate=July 24, 2012 |df= }} |- | ''[[Fistful of Frags]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 21 December 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/fistful-of-frags/news/release-imminent2 |title=Release imminent! |date=19 December 2007 |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 9 May 2014{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265630/ |title=Fistful of Frags |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Garry's Mod]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | style="white-space: nowrap;" | 24 December 2004 | 29 November 2006{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/4000/ |title=Garry's Mod |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Gunman Chronicles]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | | 20 November 2000 | The mod was originally under development for the [[Quake engine|''Quake'' engine]], but switched twice: first to the [[Quake II engine|''Quake II'' engine]] and finally to [[GoldSrc]], the engine used by Half-Life, which it remained using for its standalone release. |- | ''[[Hacx|Hacx: Twitch 'n Kill]]'' | ''[[Doom II]]'' | September 1997 | 9 October 2010{{cite web |url=http://drnostromo.com/hacx/page.php?content=info |title=Hacx 1.2 and Hacx 2.0 |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | ''Half-Life: Threewave'' | ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'' | 1996 | unreleased | The creator of the original Threewave CTF mod Dave "Zoid" Kirsch was hired by Valve to port it to the [[GoldSrc|GoldSrc engine]]. However, the game was never released, and its unfinished code was found years later in a [[Source code leak|leak]] and polished by community members to allow for public play.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fK0BC-WPJPo |title=Half-Life: Threewave - Valve's Unreleased Game |accessdate=27 January 2017}} |- | ''[[The Haunted: Hell's Reach]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | 2010 | 25 October 2011{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/43190/ |title=The Haunted: Hell's Reach |accessdate=14 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[Insurgency: Modern Infantry Combat|Insurgency]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/insurgency |title=Insurgency Mod for Half-Life 2 |accessdate=21 August 2016}} | January 22, 2014{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/222880/| title=Insurgency on Steam |accessdate=21 August 2016}} | |- | ''[[Killing Floor (video game)|Killing Floor]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]'' | 2005 | 14 May 2009{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/1250/ |title=Killing Floor |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | The game received [[Killing Floor 2|a sequel]] in 2015.{{cite web |url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/05/08/killing-floor-2-announced/ |title=Loadsa Muties: Killing Floor 2 Announced With More Gore |date=8 May 2014 |author=Alice O'Connor |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |accessdate=13 March 2016}} |- | ''[[Natural Selection 2]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 31 October 2002 | 31 October 2012 | ''Natural Selection 2'' is a sequel to the original mod named ''[[Natural Selection (video game)|Natural Selection]]''. |- | ''[[Nexuiz]]'' | ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'' | 2001 | 31 May 2005 | The game received [[Nexuiz (2012 video game)|a sequel with the same name]] by [[IllFonic]] and the project was [[Fork (software development)|forked]] by its community and renamed ''[[Xonotic]]''. |- | ''[[No More Room in Hell]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 31 October 2011{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/no-more-room-in-hell/news/nmrih-beta-10-release |title=NMRiH Beta 1.0 Release |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 31 October 2013 | |- | ''[[Nuclear Dawn]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]] | | 26 September 2011 | |- | ''[[Project Reality|Project Reality: BF2]]'' | ''[[Battlefield 2]]'' |8 July 2005 |30 May 2015{{cite web |url=http://www.realitymod.com/forum/f380-project-reality-news/134902-project-reality-bf2-v1-3-standalone-released.html |title=Project Reality: BF2 v1.3 Standalone Released! |accessdate=22 June 2017}} |A sequel was announced in 2009 based initially on [[C4 Engine]] then shifted to [[CryEngine|CryEngine 3]] but was never released. On October 10, 2014 Project Reality:BF2 developers announced [[Squad (video game)|Squad]], based on [[Unreal Engine|Unreal Engine 4]], which is still in early access. |- | ''[[Red Alert: A Path Beyond]]'' | ''[[Command & Conquer: Renegade]]'' | 29 July 2004{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/red-alert-a-path-beyond/news/renegade-alert-v993b-released |title=Renegade Alert v993b Released! | accessdate=25 March 2016}} | 14 September 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/red-alert-a-path-beyond/news/brrriiiiiiinnng |title=BRRRIIIIIIINNNG!!! | accessdate=25 March 2016}} | Original mod was called ''Renegade Alert''. |- | ''[[Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 2003]]'' and ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004|2004]]''. | 10 October 2003{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/red-orchestra/news/red-orchestra-released |title=Red Orchestra - Released! |accessdate=7 October 2016}} | 14 March 2006{{cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/1200/ |title=Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 |accessdate=7 October 2016}} | The original mod was called ''[[Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45#Red Orchestra: Combined Arms|Red Orchestra: Combined Arms]]''. The game has also received [[Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad|a sequel]]. |- | ''[[Renegade X]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament 3]]'' | September 2009 | 28 January 2012 (''Black Dawn'' standalone release)
26 February 2016 (multiplayer standalone release). | The game has not been fully released. |- | ''[[Smokin' Guns]]'' | ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' | 2001 | 5 January 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/games/smokin-guns/news/smokin-guns-release |title=Smokin' Guns release |accessdate=13 March 2016}} |''Smokin' Guns'' was originally developed by Iron Claw Interactive under the name ''Western Quake 3'' until 2005. A new team, going under the name of Smokin' Guns Productions, released ''Smokin' Guns'' 1.0 as a standalone version based on the [[Open-source software|open-source]] ''Quake III'' engine in January 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausgamers.com/news/read/2693847/SmokinGuns.html |title=Smokin' Guns, a Free Western Shooter - AusGamers |accessdate=2010-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707191246/http://www.ausgamers.com/news/read/2693847/SmokinGuns.html |archivedate=July 7, 2011 }} |- | ''[[The Stanley Parable]]'' | ''[[Half-Life 2]]'' | 27 July 2011 | 17 October 2013 | |- | ''[[Sven Co-op]]'' | ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' | 19 January 1999 | 22 January 2016 | This game had the longest delay between its mod release and its standalone release compared to all other games on this list: just over seventeen years. |- | ''[[Tactical Ops: Assault on Terror]]'' | ''[[Unreal Tournament]]'' | 23 December 1999 | 24 April 2002 | |- | ''[[Team Fortress Classic]]'' | ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'' | 1996 | 7 April 1999 | The original mod (simply named ''Team Fortress'') was a mod for ''Quake'', but it was acquired by [[Valve Corporation]] and ported to [[GoldSrc]] for its standalone release as ''Team Fortress Classic''. The game has also received [[Team Fortress 2|a sequel]]. |- | ''[[Tiberian Sun Reborn]]'' | ''[[Command & Conquer: Renegade]]'' | 2008 | 1 June 2013{{cite web |url=http://www.indiedb.com/games/ts-reborn/news/blog-15-release |title=Blog 15 - Release |accessdate=25 March 2016}} | Original mod was called ''CnC Reborn''. |- | style="white-space: nowrap;" |''[[Tower Unite]]'' | ''[[Garry's Mod]]'' | 7 July 2009 | 8 April 2016 | Tower Unite is the standalone version of GMod Tower by Pixeltail Games, which was a mod for Garry's Mod. Garry's Mod, in turn, was a mod for ''[[Half-Life 2]]''. |- | ''[[Tremulous]]'' | ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' | 11 August 2005 | 31 March 2006 | Inspired by the Quake II modification Gloom, which also features alien vs human teams with distinct user classes. Following the release of the Quake III Arena source code under the [[GPL]] on August 19, 2005, the developers decided to rework Tremulous into a standalone, [[free and open source]] game. |- | ''[[Urban Terror]]'' | ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' | September 1999 | April 2007 | Urban Terror is a freeware multiplayer [[first-person shooter]] [[Mod (computer gaming)#Total conversion|total conversion]] of [[id Software]]'s ''[[Quake III Arena]]''. Released as a free standalone game in 2007 utilizing [[ioquake3]].[http://www.urbanterror.info/news Urban Terror: News] Retrieved 2009-09-16 While the engine is [[Open-source software|open source]], Urban Terror's assets and code are [[closed source]]. |- | ''[[Wings of Dawn]]'' | ''[[Freespace 2]]'' | | 8 April 2015{{cite web| url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/wings-of-dawn/news/wings-of-dawn-new-release |title=Wings of Dawn new release |accessdate=25 March 2016}} | |- | ''[[World of Padman]]'' | ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' | 19 June 2004{{cite web| url=http://www.indiedb.com/games/world-of-padman/news/wop-has-finally-arrived |title=WoP has finally arrived! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 1 April 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.indiedb.com/games/world-of-padman/news/wop-standalone-its-done |title=WoP Standalone - It's done! |accessdate=13 March 2016}} |Began as [[mod (computer gaming)|mod]]ification for the game ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' titled ''PadMod'' created in the year 2004. After the [[source code]] for ''Quake III Arena'' was released, the game became standalone.{{cite web | url = http://www.insidemacgames.com/news/story.php?ArticleID=15250 | title = World of Padman Reviewed | date = 2007-06-13 |author=Cord Cruse |publisher = [[Inside Mac Games]] | accessdate = 2008-07-14 }} The idea is based on the Padman comic strip for the magazine PlayStation Games created by the professional cartoon artist Andreas 'ENTE' Endres, who is also the man who made many of the maps included with the game in 1998. Later versions run on an enhanced version of the [[ioquake3]] engine. |- | ''[[Wreckage (video game)|Wreckage]]'' | ''[[Crysis Wars]]'' | 22 December 2011{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/wreckage/news/wreckage-release-release |title=Wreckage - Release, release |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | 4 May 2012{{cite web |url=http://www.moddb.com/mods/wreckage/news/wreckage-standalone-released2 |title=WRECKAGE - STANDALONE RELEASED |accessdate=13 March 2016}} | |- | style="white-space: nowrap;" |''[[X-Men: The Ravages of Apocalypse]]'' | ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'' | 30 November 1997 | 2006 | Despite being officially licensed by [[Marvel Comics]], the game required Quake to be installed in order to play. In 2006, it was released as [[freeware]] and modified to not require Quake. |} ==See also== * [[List of game engines]] * [[List of Source engine mods]] * [[List of GoldSrc engine mods]] * [[List of Unreal Engine games]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Video games derived from modifications}} [[Category:Technology-related lists]] [[Category:Video game lists|Mod]]

{{lowercase|title=mTropolis}} '''mTropolis''' (pronounced "metropolis") was an [[open-architecture]] multimedia programming application aimed at enabling rapid development of [[multimedia]] titles.[https://web.archive.org/web/20000823023742/http://www.cbd-hq.com/articles/2000/000501gh_mtropolis.asp mTropolis, the Greatest CBD Tool that Never Was] by Glen Hunter, Mojo Productions Inc. (2000, archived) It was developed by mFactory (pronounced "em-factory") and introduced in 1995. It introduced [[object-oriented]] concepts such as reusable objects, modifiers and behaviors into the multimedia authoring space dominated by [[Macromedia]]'s Director software. mTropolis was bought in 1997 by [[Quark, Inc.|Quark]], which moved development from [[Burlingame, California]] to [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] and then [[End-of-life (product)|cancelled the product]] one year later. Despite efforts by its fervent users to attempt to save their investment and beloved tool, negotiations and even a possible purchase offer never came to fruition.{{cite web|last=Lindsay |first=Greg |title=The software that refused to die |url=http://salon.com/21st/feature/1998/06/10feature.html |accessdate=2016-06-27 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000503164742/http://salon.com/21st/feature/1998/06/10feature.html |archivedate=May 3, 2000|publisher=[[salon.com]] }} ==History== mTropolis (pronounced "metropolis") competed in the [[Interactive media|interactive]] multimedia product space dominated in the 1990s by [[Adobe Director|Macromedia Director]]. The software's maker, mFactory (pronounced "em-factory"), founded in 1992, variously positioned mTropolis as an alternative and as an adjunct to Director. mTropolis was bought by [[Quark, Inc.|Quark]] in 1997. The use of behaviors in mTropolis spurred [[Macromedia]] on to introduce behaviors in Director 6.0.
I was there when Seery, Shepherd, meself and probably Greggy went over to the Mtrop user meetings. We straight out stole [behaviors] from them. - ''Alex Zavatone (ex Macromedia) on the Direct-L Mailing List, Tue, 9 Sep 2008''
While multimedia CD-ROM authoring has largely been rendered irrelevant by online content distribution, mTropolis remains an interesting study in application design, and held a loyal following for many years.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} ==Paradigm== The development environment was very different from the other tools around at the time - [[Apple Computer]]'s [[HyperCard]] and others had a card based metaphor, and [[Macromedia Director]] had a film metaphor (the content area is called The Stage, the time line The Score, an assets library named The Cast, etc.). In mTropolis there were sections, subsections, and scenes. Assets would be placed onto the scene, and then combinations of behaviors and modifiers would be dragged onto the assets. Powerful interaction and animation could be created by making different modifiers send messages to each other, allowing a user to create something impressive fairly quickly, without any typing. There was a simple programming language, accessed via a Miniscript modifier, but most of the programming was achieved by attaching standard behaviors and modifiers, and making selections within the modifier pop-up menus. ==Technical Issues== According to [[Starship Titanic]] author [[Douglas Adams]], his team had originally selected mTropolis 1.0 for its development platform but it had to be abandoned for unspecified technical insufficiencies in favor of an in-house tool.{{cite web | last = Adams | first = Douglas | title = Why isn't Starship Titanic on the Macintosh? | url=http://www.starshiptitanic.com/game/mac.html | accessdate = 2008-05-31 }} ===Miniscript Limitations=== One criticism of the tool was that the integrated programming language, Miniscript, was lacking key features necessary for common tasks. Because mTropolis was conceived around a [[visual programming language|visual programming]] metaphor, mFactory engineers intentionally omitted [[control flow|control constructs]] such as [[conditional loop]]s. To remedy such limitations, the third-party developer AX Logic produced the commercially-available Alien Studio modifier as a drop-in replacement for Miniscript. ===File Format=== The advent in version 1.1 of the mTropolis browser plug-in for [[Netscape Navigator]], dubbed ''mPire,'' exposed a core architectural shortcoming. The binary file format was not cross-platform; in order to make a mTropolis element available for embedding on a web page, the author was required to save a Macintosh version and a separate Windows version. Hence the web server had to store redundant copies of the same content, consuming disk space and necessitating the use of loader pages to serve the file appropriate for the end user's operating system. ===Macintosh-Only Authoring=== While playback engines existed for both the Macintosh and Windows platforms, the mTropolis authoring system itself only ran on the Mac. ==Release history== ===mTropolis 1.0=== January 1995: Released at [[Macworld Conference & Expo|MacWorld San Francisco]]. Retail price $4,495. ===mTropolis 1.1=== May 1996: Added support for [[QuickTime VR]] 1.0. Retail price $1,195. October 1996: mFactory releases beta 1 of the mPire browser plug-in. ===mTropolis 2.0=== March 1997: mFactory announces pre-order sales availability for version 2.0, due to ship in "the second half of May." Retail price $995. May 1997: Quark, Inc. purchases mFactory. March 1998: Quark announces that v2.0 would be furnished free-of-charge to registered mTropolis v1 customers, but that the product will not be made available for general purchase.{{cite news | last = Landwehr | first = Rebecca | title = mFactory shut down by Quark | url=http://denver.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/1998/03/30/story5.html | accessdate = 2008-06-01 | date=1998-03-29}} ==Titles Created with mTropolis== Due to the way the mTropolis Player was separate from developer content, by viewing the files, it is easy to tell if a title was developed with mTropolis. A few [[CD-ROM]]s were created using mTropolis, including the [[BAFTA]] award winning [[MindGym]], [[Scott Kim]]'s [[Obsidian (1997 video game)|Obsidian]], A Sharp's [[King of Dragon Pass]], the [[Muppets]] Treasure Island, Voyager's Fun With Architecture and The Magic World of [[Beatrix Potter]]. == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20000824121113/http://www.mtropolis.com/ mtropolis.com] (archived 2000) {{DEFAULTSORT:Mtropolis}} [[Category:Multimedia software]] [[Category:Authoring systems]] [[Category:Orphan works]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Manathil Uruthi Vendum | image = ManathilUruthi.jpg | caption = LP Records Cover | director = [[K. Balachander]]{{Citation | title = Manathil Uruthi Vendum | publisher = IMDb | url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0154830/ | accessdate = 2008-12-21 }} | producer = Rajam Balachander
Pushpa Kandaswamy | writer = [[K. Balachander]] | narrator = | starring = [[Suhasini Mani Ratnam|Suhasini]]
[[Sridhar (Kannada actor)|Sridhar]]
[[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]]
[[Ramesh Aravind]]
[[Vivek (actor)|Vivek]] | music = [[Ilaiyaraaja]] | cinematography = [[R. Raghunatha Reddy]] | editing = Ganesh - Kumar | studio = [[Kavithalayaa Productions]] | distributor = [[Kavithalayaa Productions]] | released = 23 October 1987 | runtime = 147 minutes | country = India | language = Tamil | budget = | gross = }} '''''Manathil Uruthi Vendum''''' (English: Need Brave Heart) is a 1987 Indian [[Tamil language]] [[Drama film]] directed by [[Kailasam Balachander|K. Balachander]] starring [[Suhasini Mani Ratnam|Suhasini]], [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], [[Ramesh Aravind]], [[Sridhar (Kannada actor)|Sridhar]], [[Vivek (actor)|Vivek]], [[Lalitha Kumari]], [[Chithra (actress)|Chithra]], Chandrakanth and Yamuna. [[Rajinikanth]], [[Sathyaraj]], and [[Vijayakanth]] make guest appearances. The film was dubbed in Telugu as ''Sister Nandini''.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JOufDOkigdo == Plot == This is the story of Nandini, a nurse, played by [[Suhasini Mani Ratnam|Suhasini]]. She is the sole bread winner of her huge family including six siblings and unemployed parents, and she faces many hurdles in her life including a divorce, loss of a brother, an eloped sister, a failed second romance and an organ donation. She handles them with dignity and wins the hearts of one and all including her suspicious ex-husband when she donates him her kidney. [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]] plays the role of a dedicated Doctor, who inspires Nandini to take the ultimate decision in life to continue serving her patients. ==Cast== *[[Suhasini Mani Ratnam|Suhasini]] as Nandhini *[[Sridhar (Kannada actor)|Sridhar]] as Suriya *[[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]] as Dr. Arthanari (Debut) *[[Ramesh Aravind]] as Ramesh (Debut) *[[Vivek (actor)|Vivek]] as Vivek (Debut) *[[Lalitha Kumari]] as Vasu (Debut) *[[Chithra (actress)|Chithra]] *[[Ganeshkar]] as Ganesh *[[Kavithalaya Krishnan]] as Gothandam *[[Charle]] as Patient (Guest Appearance) *[[Poovilangu Mohan]] as Patient (Guest Appearance) *Chandrakanth *Yamuna *Director [[Vasanth]] as Reporter (Guest Appearance) '''Special Appearance in Vangaala Kadale Song''' *[[Rajinikanth]] *[[Vijayakanth]] *[[Sathyaraj]] ==Production== While assisting with the script for the film in 1987, Balachandar offered Vivek an acting role of Suhasini's brother in the film, which he decided to pursue thus made his acting debut in the film.http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/interviews/article249658.ece Recalling his experience: "I remember the first day of my shooting [..] I was asked to come running down the stairs. I did the shot to his satisfaction. But in doing so I hurt my toes. But I did not want to show it to him. But after a few minutes the blood was oozing from the wound. KB sir saw it and asked me immediately to attend to it".http://www.thehindu.com/2005/09/15/stories/2005091503060200.htm == Soundtrack == {{Infobox album | name = Manathil Uruthi Vendum | type = soundtrack | artist = [[Ilaiyaraaja]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|df=yes|1987 || }} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | language = [[Tamil language|Tamil]] | label = | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The music composed by [[Ilaiyaraaja]], with the lyrics written by [[Vaali (poet)|Vaali]].{{tracklist | collapsed = | headline = | extra_column = Singers | total_length = | all_writing = | all_lyrics = | all_music = | writing_credits = | lyrics_credits = | music_credits = | title1 = Manathil Uruthi Vendum | note1 = | writer1 = | lyrics1 = | music1 = | extra1 = [[K.
